bail: @ An amount of money that a person who has been accused of a crime pays to a law court so that he or she can be released until his or her trial. The payment is a way of making certain that the person will return to court for trial.
He was released on bail of $ 100,000.
She was yesterday bailed for three weeks on a drunk driving charge.
Because of a previous conviction, the judge refused to grant bail.
Her parents have agreed to put up/stand bail for her.
@ To remove water from a boat using a container.
The boat's sinking! Start bailing quickly!
I'd float around for hours fishing and bailing out the water leaking in.
@ To stop doing something or leave a place before something is finished.
It was so boring I bailed early.
collateral: @ Valuable property owned by someone who wants to borrow money, that they agree will become the property of the company or person who lends the money if the debt is not paid back.
She used/put up her house as collateral for a loan.
@ Connected but less important, or of the same family although not directly related.
alley: @ A narrow road or path between buildings.
She walked quickly down the alley.
I ran down the alley and up the back stairs.
@ A path in a park or garden, esp. with trees or bushes on both sides.
boot: @ A type of shoe that covers the whole foot and lower part of the leg.
Don't forget your boots and shin pads.
@ A covered space at the back of a car, for storing things in.
I always keep a blanket and a toolkit in the boot for emergencies.
Stolen goods were found in the boot of her car.
He gave the ball a good boot.
They booted him in the head.
@ A metal device attached to the wheel of an illegally parked car that will only be removed when the owner pays an amount of money.
@ When a computer boots (up), it becomes ready for use by getting the necessary information into its memory, and when you boot (up) a computer, you cause it to do this.
Before you can do anything, you have to boot up.
The PC should now boot from the CD-ROM drive and the installation will begin.
Boot up your computer and log onto your company's intranet.

the boot: @ The situation in which your job is taken away from you, usually because you have done something wrong or badly.
